title: Zoogeography
description:
The study of how animal species are distributed across the planet.
Example: Global animal distribution

title: Animal Distribution
description:
The natural geographical range where a species is found.
Example: Lion in Africa

title: Dispersal
description:
The movement of organisms from one place to another.
Example: Bird migration

title: Vicariance
description:
Separation of species due to geological events.
Example: Continental drift

title: Range Expansion
description:
Expansion of a species' range due to favorable conditions.
Example: Coyotes expanding north

title: Range Contraction
description:
Reduction in a species’ range due to unfavorable conditions.
Example: Tigers losing habitat

title: Habitat Fragmentation
description:
Breaking up of habitats, affecting species populations.
Example: Deforestation effects

title: Ecological Niche
description:
The role a species plays in its environment.
Example: Coral reef fish niches

title: Geographical Barrier
description:
Physical features preventing species movement.
Example: Oceans, mountains

title: Endemic Species
description:
Species restricted to a specific area.
Example: Kangaroo in Australia

title: Cosmopolitan Species
description:
Species found worldwide in many habitats.
Example: Pigeons

title: Native Species
description:
A species naturally occurring in an area.
Example: Bald eagle in North America

title: Introduced Species
description:
A species introduced to a new habitat by humans.
Example: Cane toads in Australia

title: Invasive Species
description:
A non-native species that disrupts local ecosystems.
Example: Zebra mussels

title: Migratory Species
description:
Species that move between habitats seasonally.
Example: Monarch butterflies

title: Resident Species
description:
Species that stay in one habitat year-round.
Example: Deer in forests

title: Extirpation
description:
Local extinction of a species from an area.
Example: Wolves in Yellowstone

title: Extinction
description:
Complete disappearance of a species.
Example: Dodo bird

title: Rewilding
description:
Reintroducing species to restore ecosystems.
Example: European bison reintroduction

title: Ecological Corridor
description:
A habitat connection aiding wildlife movement.
Example: Wildlife bridges

title: Species Richness
description:
The number of different species in an area.
Example: Amazon rainforest

title: Species Abundance
description:
The number of individuals of a species in an area.
Example: Deer population

title: Biotic Homogenization
description:
Loss of unique species, leading to uniform ecosystems.
Example: Invasive species spread

title: Ecoregion
description:
A large region characterized by distinct species.
Example: Sahara Desert ecoregion

title: Ecotone
description:
A transitional zone between two ecosystems.
Example: Mangrove forests

title: Island Biogeography
description:
Study of species diversity on islands.
Example: Galápagos finches

title: Adaptive Radiation
description:
Rapid evolution of species from a common ancestor.
Example: Sharks and dolphins

title: Convergent Evolution
description:
Unrelated species evolving similar traits.
Example: Darwin’s finches

title: Divergent Evolution
description:
Related species developing distinct traits.
Example: Woodpeckers and cuckoos

title: Sympatric Distribution
description:
Species living in overlapping areas.
Example: Mountain and valley species

title: Allopatric Distribution
description:
Species separated by physical barriers.
Example: Baboons in Africa

title: Parapatric Distribution
description:
Species with adjacent but non-overlapping ranges.
Example: Butterflies on mountain slopes

title: Metapopulation
description:
A population of spatially separated groups.
Example: Wolf packs

title: Keystone Species
description:
A species crucial to ecosystem stability.
Example: Sea otters

title: Umbrella Species
description:
A species whose conservation benefits many others.
Example: Tigers

title: Indicator Species
description:
A species signaling ecosystem health.
Example: Frogs in wetlands

title: Flagship Species
description:
A well-known species used in conservation.
Example: Pandas

title: Charismatic Megafauna
description:
Large, appealing animals that attract conservation support.
Example: Elephants

title: Trophic Cascade
description:
Ecological chain reactions caused by predator-prey dynamics.
Example: Wolves and elk

title: Biogeographic Rule
description:
Patterns governing species distribution.
Example: Temperature affecting size

title: Bergmann's Rule
description:
Larger animals occur in colder climates.
Example: Fox ears in different climates

title: Allen’s Rule
description:
Appendages are shorter in colder climates.
Example: Fur color in humid areas

title: Gloger’s Rule
description:
Darker pigmentation occurs in humid environments.
Example: Island dwarfism and gigantism

title: Foster’s Rule
description:
Island species evolve differently from mainland species.
Example: Lemurs in Madagascar

title: Endemism
description:
Species restricted to a specific location.
Example: Tuataras

title: Paleoendemism
description:
Ancient species now restricted in range.
Example: Cichlid fish

title: Neoendemism
description:
Newly evolved species found only in one area.
Example: Nearctic, Neotropical, Palearctic, etc.

title: Biogeographic Realm
description:
Large-scale divisions of the world based on fauna.
Example: Bison in North America

title: Nearctic Region
description:
Biogeographic region covering North America.
Example: Amazon rainforest fauna

title: Neotropical Region
description:
Region covering South and Central America.
Example: Siberian tiger

title: Palearctic Region
description:
Region covering Europe and northern Asia.
Example: African elephant

title: Afrotropical Region
description:
Region covering Africa and parts of Arabia.
Example: Bengal tiger

title: Indomalayan Region
description:
Region covering South and Southeast Asia.
Example: Kangaroo

title: Australasian Region
description:
Region covering Australia and nearby islands.
Example: Hawaiian honeycreepers

title: Oceanian Region
description:
Region covering isolated Pacific islands.
Example: Emperor penguin

title: Antarctic Region
description:
Region covering Antarctica and the Southern Ocean.
Example: Bali myna distribution

title: Wallace Line
description:
Imaginary boundary separating Asian and Australian fauna.
Example: Sulawesi species mix

title: Weber Line
description:
Boundary slightly east of Wallace Line.
Example: Australia-New Guinea species

title: Lydekker Line
description:
Boundary marking the eastern edge of Australian fauna.
Example: Pangaea breakup

title: Continental Drift
description:
The gradual movement of continents over time.
Example: Continental movement

title: Plate Tectonics
description:
Theory explaining the movement of Earth's plates.
Example: Supercontinent breakup

title: Pangaea
description:
Supercontinent that existed 300 million years ago.
Example: Ancient landmass

title: Laurasia
description:
Northern portion of Pangaea.
Example: Ancient supercontinent

title: Gondwana
description:
Southern portion of Pangaea.
Example: Galápagos tortoise

title: Island Endemism
description:
Endemism occurring on islands.
Example: Amazonian river dolphins

title: Continental Endemism
description:
Endemism occurring on mainlands.
Example: Hawaiian Islands

title: Archipelago
description:
A group of islands in a common region.
Example: Ice Age refuges

title: Refugia
description:
Areas where species survived during climatic shifts.
Example: Ginkgo tree

title: Relict Species
description:
Species that remain from an ancient lineage.
Example: Darwin’s finches

title: Species Radiation
description:
Rapid diversification of species from one ancestor.
Example: Chameleons in Madagascar

title: Adaptive Endemism
description:
Endemism due to adaptations to local conditions.
Example: Dispersed populations of alligators

title: Disjunct Distribution
description:
Species populations separated over vast distances.
Example: Madagascar

title: Endemic Hotspot
description:
Areas rich in endemic species.
Example: Andes mountains

title: Endemic Bird Area
description:
Regions identified for their high endemic bird diversity.
Example: Southern Hemisphere marsupials

title: Gondwanan Distribution
description:
Distribution pattern of species linked to Gondwana.
Example: Amazon rainforest species

title: Tropical Endemism
description:
Endemism occurring in tropical climates.
Example: Alpine flowers

title: Temperate Endemism
description:
Endemism occurring in temperate climates.
Example: Himalayan blue sheep

title: Mountain Endemism
description:
Endemism occurring in mountain regions.
Example: Great Barrier Reef species

title: Marine Endemism
description:
Endemism occurring in oceanic habitats.
Example: Lake Victoria cichlids

title: Freshwater Endemism
description:
Endemism occurring in freshwater ecosystems.
Example: Tasmanian devil

title: Endemic Mammals
description:
Mammals restricted to a specific region.
Example: Galápagos marine iguana

title: Endemic Reptiles
description:
Reptiles restricted to a specific region.
Example: Axolotl

title: Endemic Amphibians
description:
Amphibians restricted to a specific region.
Example: Amazonian butterflies

title: Endemic Insects
description:
Insects restricted to a specific region.
Example: Baobab trees

title: Endemic Plants
description:
Plants restricted to a specific region.
Example: Devil’s Hole pupfish

title: Endemic Fish
description:
Fish restricted to a specific region.
Example: Tropical biodiversity shift

title: Endemism Gradient
description:
Gradual change in endemism across regions.
Example: Equator species increase

title: Latitudinal Diversity Gradient
description:
Increase in species richness towards the tropics.
Example: Comparing jungle and savanna species

title: Species Turnover
description:
Change in species composition between habitats.
Example: Amazon vs. Congo rainforest species

title: Beta Diversity
description:
Measure of species turnover between ecosystems.
Example: Coral reef diversity

title: Alpha Diversity
description:
Diversity of species within a single habitat.
Example: Madagascar's isolated species
